Package edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.graph

Class DummyAction

java.lang.Object
edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.graph.DummyAction
public class DummyAction extends Object
Dummy actions are special actions which are sometimes created to update a state when a traditional action occurs. Dummy actions are not authored as part of a planning problem but are implied by certain state update operations.
Author:
Stephen G. Ware

  • Method Details

    • surprise

      public static Action surprise(State state, Event event, State beliefs)
      A surprise action is a dummy action used to update an character's beliefs when the character observes an action which they don't believe is possible. When an action occurs, and some character observes it, but that action's precondition is not satisfied in that character's beliefs, the character should first update their beliefs and then apply the action's effect to their beliefs. A surprise dummy action is used to perform that initial belief update which occurs before taking the real action in the character's beliefs.

      The precondition of a dummy surprise action is always false to signal that the character was not able to foresee this outcome. The effects of a dummy surprise action are changes which need to be made to the character's beliefs before they observe the real action occur. A dummy surprise action has no consenting or observing characters.

      If the character already believes the real action is possible (in other words, no changes need to be made to their beliefs), this method returns null.

      Because the real action's precondition could be a disjunction, there may be several different ways the character's beliefs could be changed before the real action occurs; however, modeling this would introduce epistemic uncertainty, which is not supported. The effects of a dummy surprise action are calculated like this: The method checks every clause in the real action's precondition. If a clause is satisfied in the state where the real action is happening, but not satisfied in the character's beliefs, then for every precondition in the clause which is not satisfied in the character's beliefs, an effect is added to the dummy surprise action that modifies the fluent on the left side of the precondition. The new value of the fluent is based on the kind of precondition:

      • If the precondition's operator is the equal to operator, the fluent will be set to the value that the right side of the precondition evaluates to in the state where the real action is occurring.
      • If the precondition has any other operator, the fluent will be set to unknown.
      Note that, due to the second case above, a dummy surprise action does not always modify an character's beliefs to be a state where the real action can occur. For example, consider a buy action which has the precondition that the buyer's wealth is greater than or equal to the price of the thing being bought. A second character, who believes the buyer has no money, observes the buyer buy something. A dummy surprise action is needed to update that bystandar's beliefs, because they observed an action they thought could not happen. The dummy surprise action will not update the bystander's beliefs by causing them to know exactly how much money the buyer has; rather, it will set the bystander's beliefs about the buyer's wealth to unknown, because the bystander is now uncertain about how much money the buyer has.
      Parameters:
      state - the state in which the event is occurring; the given event's precondition should be satisfied in this state
      event - the event that is occurring and being observed
      beliefs - the beliefs of an character who observes the event but may not believe its precondition is satisfied
      Returns:
      a dummy surprise action to update the observing character's beliefs before they observe the action, or null if the action's precondition is already satisfied in the character's belief state

    • update

      public static Action update(Character character, Event event, State state)
      A belief update action is a dummy action used to modify the beliefs of a character when an action's effect directly modifies the character's beliefs. We say that an action directly modifies a character's beliefs when it has an effect of the form "character c believes fluent f has value v." This is opposed an action indirectly modifying a character's beliefs when a character observes an action. For every effect in the given event of the form "character c believes fluent f has value v," this method creates a dummy action which has character c as the only observing character and an effect of the form "fluent f has value v." This dummy belief update action can then be taken in the state that reflects character c's beliefs to capture that idea that f=v and c believes f=v and c believes c believes f=v, and so on.

      If the action has no effects which directly modify the character's beliefs, this method returns null.

      Consider a tell action where character a tells character b that fluent f has value v. The effect of the action is that b believes f=v. When this method is called with b as the character, tell as the event, and the state before tell as the state, it will return a dummy belief update action which has b as its only observing character and f=v as its only effect. We can go to the state that reflects character b's beliefs and take this action. In the resulting state, f=v, but also b believes f=v, and b believes b believes f=v, etc.

      Parameters:
      character - the character for whom the dummy belief update action will be created, and the character which will be the only observing character of that dummy action
      event - the event which may have effects that directly modify the character's beliefs
      state - the state in which the event is occurring
      Returns:
      a dummy belief update action whose effects reflect the direct belief updates of the event for the character, or null if the event has no direct belief updates for that character
